Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2011 06:56PM frankandfernsmom wrote: Hi! I have been on Taxol since September of 2010 and have had absolutely no problems with it.  The only SE I can complain about is a little tingling on my toes.  Dr recommended some powder that I have not taken so cannot comment much on that.  I receive treatment in San Antonio which is 150 miles (one way) away from home once a week.  Though someone always goes with me, I do feel good enough to drive home and at times split the drive home with my husband.  Everyone is different and responds different to treatment.  I hope it works as well for you as it has for me.  Best of luck! Linda
Posts.Title: Info on Taxol rkt Heidi_Norway

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2011 09:40AM frankandfernsmom wrote: I have been a patient at MDA since May of 2009.  I have always found everyone to be VERY helpful!!  We always stay at La Quinta (Buffalo Speedway) and always get excellent advise from Ken the shuttle driver.  Yes, it does look like that part of town is a little questionable but the majority of people who stay at that hotel are MDA patients and we've never had any problems.  Front desk is always sooo nice, compassionate, and helpful.  I have met some very nice people over breakfast and the shuttle ride to MDA. MDA can be quite overwhelming but everyone is so willing to help.  I like the efficiency of it.  Even though they are testing and treating hundreds of people a day, I like the way they operate.  And you always get your scan results promptly.  I get them the day after being scanned. I hope all goes well for you.  Let us all know how your  trip went.  Wishing for the best! Linda

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2012 07:58PM frankandfernsmom wrote: Sorry to hear about your report but don't give up hope.  I was diagnosed May '09 stage IV from the get go.  Extensive bone mets. Ribs, spine, pelvis, sternum, skull.... I also had very little pain.  Most days I feel fabulous!  Able to do all normal activities and even walk about 3 miles a day for exercise.  I have done Tamoxifen, Aromasin, Taxol, Faslodex.  Currently on Xeloda with ovary suppression and Xgeva.  Don't lose hope.  From what my oncologist has told me, there are still several treatments left to use.  And with the Xeloda, they have been able to adjust the dosage to help with side effects.  The Xeloda is the first treatment where I have actually had improvement!  Hang in there.  And wishing you many pain free days. Linda

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2013 07:21PM frankandfernsmom wrote: We all have these thoughts at one time or another.  Nothing wrong with actually saying them out loud.... I make the choice everyday to live life as best I can.  Yes, there are some days that I drop my son off at school in my pajamas, come home, sit in front to the TV with my computer on my lap, and nap on and off all day.  And do I feel guilty?.... HECK NO!!!  I know that tomorrow is a new day and I will make it a better day!  Remember, EVERBODY will die some day. There are no guarantees.  I lost 2 of my best friends within a month of each other.  And they were the ones who were always worried about me!!!!  Go figure.... Anyway, it's OK to get down... it's OK to vent.... it's OK to have these thoughts... But to quote my favorite Spamalot song... "Always look on the bright side of life"!!!! Google it.  It'll make you smile Take care my friend!! Linda

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2010 02:10AM frankandfernsmom wrote: My primary onc is at MDA which is about a 6 hour drive from home.  In my hometown we only have ONE onc and though she is a wonderful person, she does not have the resources available if needed.  I also have another onc in San Antonio which is a 2 1/2 hour drive.  She however, works closely with my MDA doctor and follows her recommendations.  I guess if something serious were to happen I'd be screwed!  But I know my husband would do whatever possible to get me to SA or Houston ASAP.  It can be done.  I would find an onc you feel comfortable with and drive the distance. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2010 09:54AM frankandfernsmom wrote: Just saw my oncologist yesterday and complained of the same thing. I already had rosacea but had now really had any bad break outs since 2003.  The bumps on my head were taken care of with an antibiotic my secondary oncologist had given me. My oncologist at MDA said that Taxol does cause acne as does the steroid.  She is recommending that we lower the dose of steroid or even stop it all together as I have not had any reaction so far to the taxol.  She also prescribed Clindamycin Phosphate Lotion (1%) and Finacea which I have used in the past to treat rosacea.  I just started using it last night so I will let you know how it works.  My face was BAD!!  Acne, red, rash-like, dry, and painful.  I told her I can handle being bald but this acne SUCKS!!!!!  She also recommended a gentle face lotion such as Aveeno or Neutrogena.  But to use one specifically for the face, not body lotion.  Like I said, I will let you know soon how it is working.  I hope you find relief soon!!  Linda

Posts.Title: Five Questions - Frankandfernsmom cmhartley texasrose361

Posts.Content: May 14, 2013 10:35AM frankandfernsmom wrote: Finally!!  I have time to answer my 5 questions!!  Sorry it took me so long..... I was born in Houston, TX but raised (or reared) in Del Rio, TX.  Woo-Hoo!!  The big city!!!  The reason I was born in Houston is because I was adopted through Catholic Charities.  I tried finding out information about my biological family when initially diagnosed, but birth mom was not willing to share much.  All I know is that my birthmom was around 23 years old and of Mexican descent and that my birthfather was 56 years old and of Czech descent.  Hmmmm.... makes me wonder what happened there.... Doesn't seem concentual to me.... ANYWAY.... I was adopted and raised by my PARENTS who were wonderful!!! They had previously adopted my brother before me.  I had a great childhood filled with love and pretty much just lived a normal life.  I graduated from Texas A&M University with a degree in Education Curriculum and Instruction and taught Math for 21 years.  A few years at the local HS but the majority at middle school.  Totally  LOVE middle school.  I know.... crazy!!!!  The majority of my years teaching were here in Del Rio, but we did live in Brownsville, TX where I taught math for 9 years.  When I was about to start my first chemo is when my husband suggested that I take an early disability retirement.  I love being home!!  I have a 9 year old that keeps me very busy!!  I am married to a University of Texas Longhorn and we will be celebrating our 13th anniversary this summer.  He has been a God-send!  He is always supportive and is always there with me at my doctor visits.  He has a wonderful family who is also available to go with me to doctors appointments, as I travel 300 miles rt once a week for treatment and @800 miles rt for quarterly checkups at MDA.  A lot of driving!!!  I have 3 wonderful sons.  The oldest just graduated with his Master of Public Service & Administration from the Bush School at Texas A&M University.  Whoop!! The tradition continues!!!  My second son just completed his 2nd year at Texas A&M as well!!  Then I have a 9 year old 3rd grader who keeps me super busy between school work, cub scouts, and baseball.  But I love every minute of it!!!  I was diagnosed stage IV from the get go in May of 2009.  I have multiple metastasis in my bones.  I have mets in my spine, pelvis, sternum, ribs, femur, and skull.  Too many to count!  I felt all gloom and doom upon hearing my prognosis but hey!!  I'M STILL HERE!!! And going strong, I might add!!!!  I have rarely felt sick during my treatments, I have good energy, I am active, and with the exception of tingling fingers and toes, I feel pretty darn good!!  Upon diagnosis, I honestly didn't think I would be around for my oldest son's graduation from college!  But here I am!! I currently have  a lesion on my liver but will have that taken care of tomorrow.  I will be in San Antonio getting cyberknife!  I am hoping that will take care of the liver problem and I can go back to living my life.  I hope to be around for a couple more years!!! As for a bucket list....I don't necessarily have a list, but if I want to do something or go somewhere, we do it!!  Life is too short!!  I have been able to visit Washington DC, Chicago, IL (went to see Oprah), Portland, California, Arizona, Vegas, Disneyland and Disneyworld, New Orleans, Puerto Vallarta, and Spain.  Next, I would like to go visit one of my best friends who lives in Colorado Springs, CO...  Hoping to go this summer.  Other than that, there are still some places here in the great state of Texas that I would like to visit.... Any suggestions?.... As for advice for the newly diagnosed... Information is very important!!  I feel you need to be proactive when it comes to your health!  Read, learn, ask questions, get to know your doctor.  If you are not satisfied, keep asking or find a doctor to your liking.  Don't be intimidated.  It's YOUR health you're dealing with!  Surround yourself with supportive people.  Let go of the negative.  Just don't allow it!!  Find a forum you are comfortable with, such as this one.  It has really helped me connecting with other women who are facing the same things. I hope I was able to give everyone a little insight into my life.  I hope it wasn't too long.... hehe Thanks Katie for asking the 5 questions! Best wishes to all!
Posts.Title: Five Questions - Frankandfernsmom cmhartley texasrose361

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 05:42PM frankandfernsmom wrote: Yes, I agree that every case is different.  For me, I have been on taxol three weeks on, one week off since the beginning of September of 2010 which is about 12 or 13 cycles, times 3 would be 36 to 39 doses.  Thank God I have been doing very well!!  Some neuropathy but not enough to take any medication or to cause any problems with walking.  My doctor recommended I take Vitamin B6 and Glutamine and it has really helped with my finger nails.  Doctor has never mentioned a limit on the number of treatments.  Doctor only says we'll continue as long as it is working I say, hang in there.  We can only try to get the most possible out of each chemo medication. Praying for the best for all of us!

Posts.Title: On to the red devil.... frankandfernsmom susan3

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2011 12:27AM frankandfernsmom wrote: KIMBO- I was diagnosed May 2009 Stage IV with extensive bone mets. Skull, sternum, ribs, pelvis, spine.... I had some pain on and off (but nothing unbearable) while I was on Tamoxifen and Aromasin. I have been on Taxol (chemo) since September of 2010 and have had very little, if any, bone pain.   I have also been told (by one oncologist) that as long as it is in the bone, we are doing ok.  That we don't want it to spread to the vital organs.  I also have another oncologist who I feel is perhaps more of a realist and will always remind me that "but it is STILL in the bones".  Meaning, you STILL have cancer...  Overall, I can't complain.  It is what it is.  Linda
